section.title: Special Cluster Options Cluster OptionsSpecial Options Special Options
section.para: The reason for these fields to be placed at the top level instead of with the rest of cluster options is simply a matter of parsing. These options are used by the configuration database which is, by design, mostly ignorant of the content it holds. So the decision was made to place them in an easy to find location.

section.title: Configuration Version, Cluster Option Cluster OptionsConfiguration Version Configuration Version
section.para: When a node joins the cluster, the cluster will perform a check to see who has the best configuration based on the fields below. It then asks the node with the highest (admin_epoch, epoch, num_updates) tuple to replace the configuration on all the nodes - which makes setting them, and setting them correctly, very important.

admin_epoch Cluster Option Cluster Optionsadmin_epoch admin_epoch

entry.para: Never modified by the cluster. Use this to make the configurations on any inactive nodes obsolete.
Never set this value to zero, in such cases the cluster cannot tell the difference between your configuration and the "empty" one used when nothing is found on disk.

Determines the type of validation being done on the configuration. If set to "none", the cluster will not verify that updates conform to the DTD (nor reject ones that don't). This option can be useful when operating a mixed version cluster during an upgrade.

section.title: Cluster Options
section.para: Cluster options, as you might expect, control how the cluster behaves when confronted with certain situations.

They are grouped into sets and, in advanced configurations, there may be more than one
This will be described later in the section on where we will show how to have the cluster use different sets of options during working hours (when downtime is usually to be avoided at all costs) than it does during the weekends (when resources can be moved to the their preferred hosts without bothering end users) . For now we will describe the simple case where each option is present at most once.
